Thank you <@UJFELMVU1>. They aren't meant for email but content titles (my bad).

I'll leave out those adjectives, so many tend to spring to one's head when brainstorming titles:grinning:

So, this guide is to teach me (like give a template for working with such brands), while helping others with a helpful resource to do the same.

text: Does anyone have a process they can recommend for when you're outlining a big piece of content? I kind of just do it by instinct but feel that I need a more laid out process especially because I'm beginning to outline content for freelancers to write and need to answer questions they may have.  For example, it might be a creative brief, or questions you always answer before you start, i.e. who is this for, what problem is it solving, etc.

elements.text: Does anyone have a process they can recommend for when you're outlining a big piece of content? I kind of just do it by instinct but feel that I need a more laid out process especially because I'm beginning to outline content for freelancers to write and need to answer questions they may have.  For example, it might be a creative brief, or questions you always answer before you start, i.e. who is this for, what problem is it solving, etc.

text:
Great thought process! Just a tidbit, not the full process:

On top of the normal headers (h2s and h3s) and bullet points, I’ll usually include 4 specific elements for the intro: context, purpose, frame and overarching question.

Intros are typically the hardest to get right, so including each of those helps the freelancers get off on the right foot.

elements.text:
Great thought process! Just a tidbit, not the full process:

On top of the normal headers (h2s and h3s) and bullet points, I’ll usually include 4 specific elements for the intro: context, purpose, frame and overarching question.

Intros are typically the hardest to get right, so including each of those helps the freelancers get off on the right foot.

text:
Great question! Some of it depends on the writers and projects. I tend to write outlines for product-focused pieces where the narrative is being influenced more by our product team, and we have specific features and nomenclature we need to cover.

For branding and thought leadership pieces (and with writers I trust), I tend to write a creative brief or what I call a "Messaging Document" that's anywhere between 2-4 pages where I go over the "why, how, what" aspects of the piece. I offer the objective of the piece, any historical/industry-specific info, how my company adds value, a little bit of competitive research and differentiator info, then I end with any relevant sources I want to make sure we include, internal or external. Hope that makes sense! I may be able to send you a template, if you're interested.

elements.text:
Great question! Some of it depends on the writers and projects. I tend to write outlines for product-focused pieces where the narrative is being influenced more by our product team, and we have specific features and nomenclature we need to cover.

For branding and thought leadership pieces (and with writers I trust), I tend to write a creative brief or what I call a "Messaging Document" that's anywhere between 2-4 pages where I go over the "why, how, what" aspects of the piece. I offer the objective of the piece, any historical/industry-specific info, how my company adds value, a little bit of competitive research and differentiator info, then I end with any relevant sources I want to make sure we include, internal or external. Hope that makes sense! I may be able to send you a template, if you're interested.

text:
When I write big content pieces, at least internally I use a 10/50/99 approach to feedback and for breaking down the project. So, I imagine it’s something I would try to replicate with freelancers as well when we look to bring some on. But depends on your relationship and how you like to work.

`<https://hackernoon.com/how-to-use-the-105099-approach-to-give-feedback-1y8433l0>`

text: I have to admit that I'm surprised that many of you provide such detailed briefs and documentation to freelancers. I've also found research/discovery/preparation to be where I spend the majority of my time as a writer and it seems like you're doing a lot of that work for them, which must work well for you or you wouldn't do it. Then again, this may explains the lower rates I'm seeing listed for freelance projects here and elsewhere. I will continue to follow this convo.

elements.text: I have to admit that I'm surprised that many of you provide such detailed briefs and documentation to freelancers. I've also found research/discovery/preparation to be where I spend the majority of my time as a writer and it seems like you're doing a lot of that work for them, which must work well for you or you wouldn't do it. Then again, this may explains the lower rates I'm seeing listed for freelance projects here and elsewhere. I will continue to follow this convo.

text: <@U0162CX5SH1> I was actually just thinking through this myself. I have heard from a content manager I admire that she get better results when providing all this upfront work - she may spend an afternoon on an outline but feels it gets her better results. But then, I'm torn, because I kind of have the same reaction you do. So then I'm left wondering, how robust should the outline be and what's the right balance so you're actually getting what you pay for?

elements.text: I was actually just thinking through this myself. I have heard from a content manager I admire that she get better results when providing all this upfront work - she may spend an afternoon on an outline but feels it gets her better results. But then, I'm torn, because I kind of have the same reaction you do. So then I'm left wondering, how robust should the outline be and what's the right balance so you're actually getting what you pay for?

text: I should add to she did say that if you continue to work with a freelancer the work you put in up front pays off because then they're more able to work w/ less guidance. So hypothetically you provide less as you move forward.

elements.text: I should add to she did say that if you continue to work with a freelancer the work you put in up front pays off because then they're more able to work w/ less guidance. So hypothetically you provide less as you move forward.

text: I struggled a lot with doing some of this work upfront, but over time, I found that it resulted in less rounds of revision. I also found that it empowered writers to make a piece their own while ensuring the company got what we needed (good SEO, the correct product names, etc.). I think a lot of it comes down to whether you want to do more work up-front or the back-end.

elements.text: I struggled a lot with doing some of this work upfront, but over time, I found that it resulted in less rounds of revision. I also found that it empowered writers to make a piece their own while ensuring the company got what we needed (good SEO, the correct product names, etc.). I think a lot of it comes down to whether you want to do more work up-front or the back-end.

text: I provide one page creative brief to my freelancers for a 1500 word article with audience, objective, research links to start, and then a mini-outline usually with key points of research I have found from others.

elements.text: I provide one page creative brief to my freelancers for a 1500 word article with audience, objective, research links to start, and then a mini-outline usually with key points of research I have found from others.

text: I also don't expect my freelancers to get product info right unless I work with them for awhile. I usually just know I'm going to add that (depends on the piece of course)

text: This may not be what you’re looking for, but I love this article from Copyhackers on page length: <https://copyhackers.com/2014/07/long-pages/>

attachments.title: Should You Write Long Pages or Short Pages?
attachments.text: How long should your pages be? People talk a lot about long copy - but it doesn't always work. Read this to see when (and why) to use long pages vs short.
attachments.fallback: Copywriting for startups and marketers: Should You Write Long Pages or Short Pages?

elements.text: This may not be what you’re looking for, but I love this article from Copyhackers on page length:

text:
Grain of salt: I have limited data to pull from here, but I've seen both work. :point_down:

I've written a pretty long one for an online course and it converted 5 figures in 24 hours. Of course, context matters a lot too. That client had a very active, 16k+ member community to tap into,  and the success wasn't (by a long shot) solely attributed to page length.

When I think about drawing up a landing page (and you've probably heard most of this!) I interview customers/potential customers to figure out what part of customer journey/stage of awareness they're in.

Then, I organize a page that's as long as it needs to be to convert. If they're basically ready to buy, and just need a place to do it, the page is really short. If they don't know the brand even exists, the page is much longer.

I like a lot of what copyhackers has to say in the article eliza linked!

When I think about drawing up a landing page (and you've probably heard most of this!) I interview customers/potential customers to figure out what part of customer journey/stage of awareness they're in.

Then, I organize a page that's as long as it needs to be to convert. If they're basically ready to buy, and just need a place to do it, the page is really short. If they don't know the brand even exists, the page is much longer.
